comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: This is just so powerful on so many levels that it is hard to look at, hard to see and hard not to feel deeply moved by it.  Three times over the past twenty four hours members of my family have mentioned the homeless and the current weather conditions and then this photograph appears, what a powerful image to reinforce that problem?  If Mrs. White paid to have this photograph taken it was not for her delectation but to be used to illustrate a point and we are the beneficiaries of her munificence.  This shot is so stark and such a powerful reminder of the brutality of poverty and how it can affect across those generations.  Super if disturbing shot Carol, thank you for the reminder!

comment.author: 72025404@N08
comment._content: amazing picture!

comment.author: 56105315@N07
comment._content: Such squalor, nothing really changes does it? For all the so called advances in humankind, poverty like this still exists.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Oh, you're welcome! Part of this Year in the Life project is that we can all relate to the (probable) weather on any given day that a photo was taken. When uploading it this morning, all I could think was how freezing cold it is today, and what must it have been like sheltering under sacks at this time of year...

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] Well said, with all their poverty they still have some sort of grace and style that is lacking in most people today.
Clothes make the man they say, and photos like these proof it.
A cap, a jacket, a hat, a dress, those clothes often  made with thick honest wool, repaired countless times, they just have something modern clothes have not.
I myself wear 1930s clothes all the time, it is an unique experience.

This looks like a temporary home, there was of course a lot of poverty back then but this shelter wouldn't last a winter.
Perhaps they have just been evicted?
Not yet in the workhouse or doss house?

So many questions and all we have are their faces who tell us so much, yet so little.

It is one of the frustrations I've felt as part of my love/hate relationship with old photos.
My imagination runs wild, my knowledge of the past jumps out but at the same time I am shouting at the photos; "Who are you, what did you go trough, what life did you have?".
The magic of old photos, they tell us so much but they make us question even more.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hab3045] That's one aspect of the satisfaction and sometimes joy that we all feel here at Library Towers when people, locations and situations are explained by our contributors' knowledge and expertise...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Absolutely no information! I'm certainly hoping that her purposes were philanthropic.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I just cannot see a lady spending money on this photograph for the beauty of the scene or the wonder of the image it presents!  This lady had the picture taken to show to others and to stir people to action just as the BBC and other channels went to Ethiopia and Somalia more recently and woke the world up to the famine and devastation on their door step.  This was not the only family living in abject poverty at that time.  I am confident and respect the memory of Mrs. White that she took this as a means of shaking up those more priviliged and those in authority to try and alleviate the poverty and bring about change!  For whatever reason she did it we now have an image that must wake us up to the plight of the homeless today and not be critical, even implied, of the lady's motivation and actions!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Okay! Hold onto your hats - I'm finding stuff about Mrs White, hopefully our Mrs White in the Munster Express... Back soon with details.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Right! In the early 1920s, a Mrs White was on the Waterford County Board of Health. In the late 1920s, a Mrs White was a Councillor on Waterford Corporation. And around similar times, a Mrs E. White was involved with Infirmary and Hospital administration and fund raising, so I'd say it's safe-ish to assume this is our Mrs E. White. The following extracts from various years of the Munster Express give some flavour of Mrs White's activities: At a meeting of the County Board of Public Assistance, Mrs White said that the destitution in Waterford was appalling, and: "she wanted to point out how exceedingly inadequate the amount given towards the relief of unemployment was. She found men with large families, some with four or five children, who were only getting about 8/- or 10/- a week, and that was given in the form of food tickets. As a result, these poor people had food for a part of the week only. But, in addition, they were left without any money to provide coal, clothing, or to pay any rent. In consequence, these poor people were getting almost hopelessly into debt ... Such a state of things was terrible..."(Munster Express, Friday, 22 January 1926) At a meeting of Waterford Corporation and the County Board of Public Assistance, Mrs. White said: "... there was a large number of the very poor congregated in the city ..." (Munster Express, Friday, 15 July 1927) She was vice-chairman(!) of the Waterford County Board of Public Assistance. She was re-elected at a meeting in July 1927 because of the "whole-hearted interest taken by Mrs. White in the business of this and other boards and committee's [sic]." (Munster Express, Friday, 29 July 1927) Mrs. White was at a Public Health Committee meeting where there was talk of a report regarding tenements. (Munster Express, Friday, 30 December 1927)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
